verses.verse: (1 He cometh to sanctification, without which, that no man putteth on Christâ€™s righteousness, he proveth4 by an argument taken of Baptism,12 and thereupon exhorteth to holiness of life,16 briefly making mention of the Law transgressed.) What (He passeth now to another benefit of Christ, which is called sanctification or regeneration.) shall we say then? Shall we continue still in (In that corruption: for though the guiltiness of sin be not imputed to us, yet the corruption remaineth still in us: the which Sanctification that followeth Justification killeth by little and little.) sin, that grace may abound? God forbid.

(The benefits of Justification and Sanctification, are always joined together inseparably, and both of them proceed from Christ, by the grace of God: Now sanctification is the abolishing of sin, that is, of our natural corruption, into whose place succeedeth the cleanness and pureness of nature reformed.) How shall we, that are (They are said of Paul to be dead to sin, which are in such sort made partakers of the virtue of Christ, that that natural corruption is dead in them, that is, the force of it is put out, and it bringeth not forth his bitter fruits: and on the other side, they are said to live to sin, which are in the flesh, that is, whom the spirit of God hath not delivered from the slavery of the corruption of nature.) dead to sin, live yet therein?

(There are three parts of this Sanctification, to wit, the dead of the old man or sin, his burial, and the resurrection of the new man, descending into us from the virtue of the death, burial, and resurrection of Christ, of which benefit our baptism is the sign and pledge.) Know ye not, that (Cross references: : Gal. 3:27) all we which have been baptized into (To the end that growing up in one with him, we should receive his strength to quench sin in us, and to make us new men.) Jesus Christ, have been baptized into his death?

(Col. 2:12) We are buried then with him by baptism into his death, that like as Christ was raised up from the dead (That Christ himself being discharged of his infirmity and weakness, might live in glory with God forever.) to the glory of the Father, so (And we which are his members rise for this end, that being made partakers of the selfsame virtue, we should begin to lead a new life, as though we were already in heaven.) we also should (Eph. 4:23; Col. 3:3; Heb. 12:1; 1 Pet. 2:1) walk in newness of life.

(1 Cor. 6:14; 2 Tim. 2:11) (The death of sin and the life of righteousness, or our ingrafting into Christ, and growing up into one with him, cannot be separated by any means, neither in death nor life, whereby it followeth, that no man is sanctified, which lived still to sin, and therefore is no man made partaker of Christ by faith, which repenteth not, and turneth not from his wickedness: for as he said before, the Law is not subverted, but established by faith.) For if we be planted with him to the (Insomuch as by the means of the strength which cometh from him to us, we so die to sin as he is dead.) similitude of his death, even so shall we (For we become every day more perfect than others: for we shall never be perfectly sanctified, as long as we live here.) be to the similitude of his resurrection,

Knowing this, that our (All our whole nature, as we are conceived and born into this world with sin, which is called old, partly by comparing that old Adam with Christ, and partly also in respect of the deformation of our corrupt nature, which we change with a new.) old man is crucified with (Our corrupt nature is attributed to Christ, not in deed, but by imputation.) him, that the body of (That naughtiness which sticketh fast in us.) sin might be destroyed, that henceforth we should not (The end of sanctification which we shoot at, and shall at length come to, to wit when God shall be all in all.) serve sin,
(He proveth it by the effects of death, using a comparison of Christ the head with his members.) For he that is dead, is freed from sin.
Wherefore, if we be dead with Christ, we believe that we shall live also with him,
Knowing that Christ being raised from the dead, dieth no more: death hath no more dominion over him.
For in that he died, he died (Once for all.) once to sin: but in that he liveth, he liveth to (With God.) God.
Likewise think ye also, that ye are dead to sin, but are alive to God in Jesus Christ our Lord.

(An exhortation to contend and strive with corruption and all the effects thereof.) Let not sin (By reigning, Saint Paul meaneth that chiefest and high rule, which no man striveth against, and if any do, yet it is in vain.) reign therefore in your mortal body, that ye should obey it in the lusts thereof:

Neither (To sin, as to a Lord or tyrant.) give ye your (Your mind and all the powers of it.) members, as (As instruments to commit wickedness withall.) weapons of unrighteousness unto sin: but give yourselves unto God, as they that are alive from the dead, and give your members as weapons of righteousness unto God.

(He granteth that sin is not yet so dead in us that it is utterly extinct: but he promised victory to them that contend manfully, because we have the grace of God given us which worketh so, that the Law is not now in us the power and instrument of sin.) For sin shall not have dominion over you: for ye are not under the Law, but under grace.

(To be under the law and under sin, signifiy all one, in respect of them which are not sanctified, as on the contrary side, to be under grace and righteousness, agree to them that are regenerate. Now these are contraries, so that one cannot agree with the other: Therefore let righteousness expel sin.) What then? shall we sin, because we are not under the Law, but under grace? God forbid.

(John 1:34; 2 Pet. 2:19) Know ye not, that to whomsoever ye give yourselves as servants to obey, his servants ye are to whom ye obey, whether it be of sin unto death, or of obedience unto righteousness?

(By nature we are slaves to sin, and free from righteousness, but by the grace of God we are made servants to righteousness, and therefore free from sin.) But God be thanked, that ye have been the servants of sin, but ye have obeyed from the heart unto the (This kind of speech hath a force in it: for he meaneth thereby that the doctrine of the Gospel is like a certain mold which we are cast into to be framed and fashioned like unto it.) form of the doctrine, whereunto ye were delivered.
Being then made free from sin, ye are made the servants of righteousness.

I speak after the manner of man, because of the infirmity of your flesh: for as ye have given your members servants to uncleanness and to iniquity, to commit iniquity, so now give your members servants unto righteousness in holiness.
For when ye were the servants of sin, ye were (Righteousness had no rule over you.) freed from righteousness.

(An exhortation to the study of righteousness and hatred of sin, the contrary ends of both, being set down before us.) What fruit had ye then in those things, whereof ye are now ashamed? For the (The reward or payment.) end of those things is death.
But now being freed from sin, and made servants unto God, ye have your fruit in holiness, and the end, everlasting life.
(Death is the punishment due to sin, but we are sanctified freely, unto life everlasting.) For the wages of sin is death: but the gift of God is eternal life, through Jesus Christ our Lord.
